Posts.Title: **NEW** Starting Chemo March 2009 ginagina celia088

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2009 06:48AM - edited Mar 26, 2009 06:51AM by Britt Gina, those drinks always look SO tempting!  Too early to imbibe at the moment! Anyway, starting my 33 weeks of rads (or, I prefer to call them, "zaps") on Monday, 3/30.  Had the "simulation" last Tuesday, where one is scanned in a CT scan and mapped and tattooed (didn't hurt at all - just a quick pinch - looks like little freckles) so they can be sure where they are exactly going to "zap" you.  Each session - Monday through Friday for 33 weeks - lasts about 15-20 minutes.  If all goes well, I should complete the zap course on May 13.  I wrote something very funny about this recently and if any of you are interested let me know and I will PM it to you. Then I have an endometrial biopsy scheduled for April Fool's Day (how appropriate) with my new gyno onco. So we shall see. Otherwise, doing ok.  Feeling physically great - staying busy.  No assignments yet, but I am continuing to try each day. The best to ALL of you - my admiration for what you are all going through is enormous! Big hugs, Maria P.S. - in answer to Marshall, I have joined the April 2009 rads group!
Posts.Title: **NEW** Starting Chemo March 2009 ginagina celia088

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2009 03:25PM Britt wrote: Luvs2sing - Wow!!!!!!!  I feel honored that you considered my response instrumental in your decision!  And gorgeous is gorgeous - you are going to look absolutely stunning with the red dress, red wrap and hoop earrings!!  It is such an empowerment color . . . . And those pictures!!!! You still look the same!  What gorgeous outfits!  Can't wait for you to post the picture . . .  And, like Janet, people always admire my hair (and thankfully I didn't have to lose it since I didn't need chemo) but was fully prepared to . . . .  even had my wigs ordered, so I do so understand. And I do woefully miss my gel nails.  Since I had all of my nodes taken out in my second surgery, artificial nails are a BIG medical no-no . . . and even professional manicures!!!  So I try to focus on my toenails - pedicures - and try to keep my feet looking as pretty as possible. Alas, valiantly trying to grow my fingernails . . .  but it's hard.  I feel so unfinished without The Full Package - and from the Wonderful World of Rads, where I am currently residing, must share that one cannot shave the underarm of the treated area AT ALL during the radiation time period - so there go my beloved tank tops and sleeveless dresses (and it's getting hot down here in FL!) for the time being . . . . well, it's still numb anyway although the arm mobility is really doing very well.  And another thing:  according to my own rads onco, can never sunbathe again.  Adios careless days on the beach without being mummified. Enough of this vanity!  But we are all women and vanity is nothing to be ashamed of . . . . as I have always said, this is all temporary.  Hair will grow back, underarm will be shaved once again, and one's nails will grow again - all after chemo and rads . . . health will trump vanity every time. Now dealing with possible side effects of Tamox, which I am slated to be going on at the conclusion of radiation (second week of May) . . . So that's it . . . . Time for a glass of Cabernet Savignon . . . . Everyone have a great holiday weekend!  Maria

You look so young!  And looking young, while going through such an arduous procedure, is indeed priceless! Xena

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2009 09:02AM Britt wrote: Hi everyone - I totally agree with everyone mentioning the "cannabis pill" - whether it is chemo, rads, surgery, Tamox, AIs, and the Endless Batteries of Tests, I strongly believe that this would be far better than the usual opiates they prescribe for us, with all of the attendant s/es of physical and psychological addiction, and other not-so-pleasant side effects . . .
Posts.Title: **NEW** Starting Chemo March 2009 ginagina celia088

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2009 06:22AM - edited Apr 11, 2009 06:24AM by Britt I have been reading the latest posts from yesterday and today. Here is what I believe:  this board should represent acceptance, tolerance, caring and concern for and of each other.  One should not be hesitant to express oneself.  Everyone does not agree with everyone else concerning certain matters.  That is where tolerance comes in. We are all in this together with the common bond of breast cancer. Christian, Catholic, Jew, agnostic, animist, athiest . . . . let us all respect each other's beliefs.  Let us not be afraid to express them with respect for others who may not agree.  And if one does not agree, do so respectfully.   Or say nothing at all.  Or just ignore that particular individual and focus on issues that are far more important - dealing with The Ailment, as I now refer to it. To quote Abraham Lincoln, "A divided house cannot stand." (okay, that's a paraphrase or a partial quote - have to hunt for my Bartlett's!) Let's be mature women . . . there is no need for such major dissension among The Warrior Princesses . . . patience, tolerance, understanding, caring, and concern. That is The Mantra. Stick together, Princesses. With the greatest respect and love to all on this Easter Weekend, Maria

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2009 02:07PM - edited Jan 24, 2009 01:45PM by Britt Okay, here is what hapepned at my appt with BS today:   Met with BS this afternoon re path report.  More good than bad - totally clear margins, but an infintisimal amount of cancer found in sentinal node - 0.2 mm - the other node taken out was negative.  BS gave me the option of an axillary node operation, noting that with such a small amount, it would only mean 2% of recurrence.  I decided not to.  She was supportive of this and mentioned the risks of an axillary node operation.  Meeting with a medical onco next week to discuss options and also with rad onco.  I feel comfortable with this decision.  The grade remained at 2, and the tumor was 2.3 cm -smaller than originally diagnosed.  So not too bad - not the absolute best! - but I can live with it!
Posts.Title: January Lumpectomy Lories Lories

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2009 01:47PM - edited Jan 24, 2009 01:49PM by Britt Hi Mom and jedking - Thinking of you both and hope that all went well yesterday!  Please let us know how it went as soon as you are able to - sending healing and positive thoughts your way! Maria
Posts.Title: January Lumpectomy Lories Lories

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2009 04:06PM Britt wrote: Hi, everyone - Thanks for all of the good thoughts coming! Katherine - Thanks so much for the good wishes!  Am following your advice to relax - BTW, where in Florida do you live? Laurie -  I hear you, believe me!  Almost drove myself bonkers imagining the Worst Possible Scenario - but then this calm descended upon me.  Whatever will happen, will happen.  No matter how much we worry about the ultimate outcome, it's not going to change it, so we just have to hope for the best - and it usually happens!  I, too, am very anxious about my nodes and also about clear margins - I had a scare with my breast MRI which showed suspicious nodules in my left breast and another in my right (where the Happy Tumor presently resides - but not for long!) - then my BS ordered a bilateral ultrasound which showed nothing - then she ordered an MRI guided biopsy - on New Year's Eve, no less! - which was an ordeal but, happily, the nodules turned out to be negative.  Of course, before the results of my path report the following Monday, I was imaging the absolute worst and was almost resigned to it - so actually since I have waited so long I have come to this calm little oasis.  My thoughts are with you this evening and I am sending a lot of positive energy towards you - you will be fine!  I think too much, myself, and I finally thought myself out (if that makes any sense). take it easy, Laurie - and report to us as soon as you feel up to it! Maria
Posts.Title: January Lumpectomy Lories Lories

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2009 02:32PM Britt wrote: Hi, Katherine and Lori - Thanks for the good wishes - I am still strangely calm - got everything organized today and am now just in the waiting mode - Lori, yes that is a sign you should stay home and rest and regain your strength - and that's really warm for Anchorage - we are almost the same temp today (it's now a "frigid" 56 degrees) Katherine, you are just a ways down the road - about three hours - are you feeling our cold spell down there also? And to Laurie - best of all best wishes!  Raising my glass to you for clear margins and negative nodes -  tomorrow it's my turn (finally!) Take care everyone and thanks again, Maria
Posts.Title: January Lumpectomy Lories Lories

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2009 08:27AM Britt wrote: Hi, all - Happy to say I survived the lumpectomy and SNB lat Friday - the latter not nearly as painful as I thought it would be.  So far, no node involvement and I didn't have to wear a drain.  Wrapped in an Ace bandage for now. However, here is a question:  my BS did not meet with me after my surgery.  She did speak with my mother who accompanied me on Friday for the surgery and told her that so far the nodes looked clear, no drain, and that she had to take out more tissue than anticipated to get clear margins.  So far, so good. My printed post-op instructions stated to remove the dressing on the second day after surgery and take a shower, and not to remove the steri-strips.  Since I am wearing an Ace and have no idea what kind of dressings I have beneath it, I called my BS's office this morning and asked for the nurse,  The receptionist told me she was busy with patients,but did schedule my post-op exam for this Friday, 1/23.  I told the receptionist that I needed to know whether or not to take the Ace off today - and if so, how to address the dressings beneath the Ace.  I still feel a little dizzy and really not up to taking a shower!  Also, BS did say she "fixed" the left breast that had suffered from the MRI guided biopsy that had a stuck artery that kept bleeding.  I want to know how she "fixed" it and whether I need to keep steri-strips on that, also. (my lumpo and SNB were on right breast) Must admit it is still tender and sore under the right armpit where the SNB was taken out - but I also want to know how many nodes were taken out and the results of my path report, if ready. Has anyone else been through something similar?
Posts.Title: January Lumpectomy Lories Lories

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2009 11:25AM Britt wrote: Hi, Tay - Thanks for responding!  Yes, my body is telling me to leave the Ace on for at least another day,and I'm following how I feel re taking a shower.  Cleansing with babywipes is working well so far, as facial wipes are for the face. Thanks again for the wishes for peace and healing - and all the best to you! - Maria
Posts.Title: January Lumpectomy Lories Lories

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2009 10:45AM Britt wrote: Hi, everyone - Katherine - so happy to hear all is going well with you.  Thanks for the advice - I did take the Ace off on Tuesday after speaking with BS nurse and put on athletic bra - right boob looks nearly indistinguishable from left one - look off the dressings with the exceptions of steris - still doing sponge baths and using facial wipes for now since right arm is still sore - big wound where they took out the nodes - no showers for now - too cold! and I meet with BS tomorrow for post-op exam - path report should be ready then.  Good luck with your results for next week.  I know that the waiting part is the most daunting!  How are you dealing with the mammosite therapy? Mom - Great good luck for tomorrow!!!!  I will be thinking of you and sending heaps of positive thoughts and energy your way.  May your SNB experience be as relatively painless as mine was! Ditto surgery - just take it easy afterwards - make sure everything you need is at arm's reach - and nothing that you have to lift your arm over your head for - indulge yourself today with a nice hot shower and some pampering! Maria

Posts.Title: RADIATION FATIGUE - POLL bluejay1 Siciliana

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2009 07:28AM Britt wrote: Hi ladies - Well, today is Zap No. 15 - have a bit of a rash and a swollen breast - still rather tired.  At least today is the day rads onco checks out the skin of the affected area.  After this, 18 zaps to go!
Posts.Title: RADIATION FATIGUE - POLL bluejay1 Siciliana

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2009 07:18AM Britt wrote: Hi everyone - Finished #19 last Friday - HUGE red inflammed bumps -itchy! - presented themselves.  Told to rest over the weekend and put on pure aloe vera and Aquafor - which just made it worse.  Woke up this morning and the bumps have multiplied, so I called my rads onco nurse early this morning and she told me to come in ASAP, which I did.  The rads onco checked it out and said it was an allergic reaction to the Aquafor and aloe vera used together, and also extreme sensitivity to the rads.  He gave me a week off from rads - told me to just use hydrocortisone 1% and nothing else. So we shall see . . . anyone else have a similar reaction?
Posts.Title: RADIATION FATIGUE - POLL bluejay1 Siciliana

Posts.Content: May 14, 2009 05:21AM Britt wrote: Hi - My Oncotype score was 12, with an 8% recurrence rate - I had one positive node out of 11 - that particular node was a micromet (2mm) - my stats are listed in my signature line - my onco was adamant that I did not need chemo - I am presently in the "home stretch" of radiation that will end on 5/27.  After that, I am going on Tamoxifen.  Of course, this is a personal decision you need to make, particularly if you want a second opinion.  I must note that your tumor was smaller than mine, and you are also a Grade 1.  However, since it is ER/PR positive, your onco may feel that the Tamoxifen will be far more helpful than the chemo.  In the interim, good luck in whatever you decide to do!
Posts.Title: oncotype DX test MED lynninpa

Posts.Content: May 14, 2009 06:37AM Britt wrote: Oh, and to clarify, I also had a lumpectomy with clear margins with no vasular invasion and I did not undergo chemotherapy.  I am 52 years old.  My ER is 96% and my PR is 99%.  I went straight to radiation.
Posts.Title: oncotype DX test MED lynninpa

Posts.Content: Britt wrote: Hi - I just received the results my CT scan today, which was taken on 2/24/09.  My med onco has scheduled me for a transvaginal and transabdominal ultrasound this Friday for the following findings:  Enlarged left hypogastric lymph node.  Bilateral ovarian lesions, likely cystic on the left, and either cystic or solid on the right.  Right extraovarian adnexal or periuterine mass effect is indeterminate.  Subserosal pedunculated fibroid not excluded.  Malignancy not excluded.  Prominence of the endometrium.   I suggest pelvic ultrasound.  The patient may need an MRI of the pelvis for further assessment.  I would recommend direct inspection of the cervix. Everything else on the report was fine.  Is there anyone out there who can interpret this in layperson's terms?  Many thanks, Maria Britt/Xena the Warrior Princess Dx 11/24/2008, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIB, Grade 2, 1/11 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Results of CT Scan? Can Anyone Interpret? Britt Britt

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2009 08:10AM Britt wrote: Thanks, jilli - It's such a difficult decision to make - do I go ahead and have it done, with the distinct possibility of all other nodes taken out being negative?  Or do I refuse the operation, opt for aggressive chemo and rads, and then find out that the cancer may have spread?  I really do not want to take the really strong chemo if it is not ncessary.  Thanks for your commiseration and good wishes - I hope that my coversation with BS  goes well,and that she is amenable to whatever I suggest - as in just taking out the Level 1 nodes.  We shall see. Shall keep you all posted.  Just such a drag since I am healing very quickly and nicely and my right arm has nearly full mobility! Have a great day! Maria

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2009 02:23PM Britt wrote: Thanks, samiam and Beesie - yes, peace of mind well worth a sore arm! Just doing gentle LE exercises to loosen it up.  Also, drain down to 40ccs for 24 hours - but I am being patient enough to wait for it to go down sufficiently to be taken out. Posts.Title: Update to Typographical Error on Pathology Report Britt Britt

Posts.Content: Britt wrote: Hi all: Here is my latest update re ALND surgery that occurred on Tuesday, 2/10 - NODES ARE NEGATIVE!!!!!! Wearing a drain - BIG HASSLE but getting used to it. Have purchased two lovely post-surgery camisoles from Amoena that have pockets for drains that are detachable.  They are rather like elongated sports bra with no snaps or hooks - one steps into it - they have great support and are made of cotton/spandex - very soft and also suitable for when one goes through radiation.  I highly recommend them.  They are also cute and kind of sexy-looking!  (check out the Amoena website for details) - they are also good for post-mast procedures - have inserts in the bra sections for foobs (which also came with each cammie - they come in white and nude). Had post-op consult with BS today - nine nodes in all were taken out - and I am happy to say that ALL ARE NEGATIVE!  Drain output still over 30 ccs for 24 hours two days in a row (which is when they will take out drain) - now down to 50ccs - so drain staying in for several more days.  Have visiting nurse coming every day to monitor the flow, check vitals, etc. - prescribed by BS. Next step is bone scan, CT scan and echo on 2/24 - then consult with med onco on 3/2 to discuss results of scans and echo and which chemo cocktail will be right for me (will they serve it in a martini glass?  Oh, wishful thinking!) So, although the operation has not been without pain - right arm is sore and rather numb - slowly beginning to exercise it with LE exercises - and despite the threat of LE which I must monitor for the rest of my life, I am relieved.  It was worth it for the peace of mind. I wish for all of you blessings and thank you all for your good wishes and prayers.   Yes, it was a tough decision to make, but I am now glad that I did. Doing a little happy dance at the moment - hope they didn't make another typo! Hugs to all - Maria Britt/Xena the Warrior Princess Dx 11/24/2008, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIB, Grade 2, 1/11 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Update to Typographical Error on Pathology Report Britt Britt

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2009 12:37PM Britt wrote: Hi, Lori - Yes, Sachi is correct - a grade 3 is the most aggressive cancer.  BTW, the real-life heroine of "Cancer Vixen" had a Grade 3 1.2 or 1.4 cm tumor with no node involvement - she went to her onco and was offered the option of what they call "Chemo Lite" which is the CMF therapy - one does not usually lose one's hair with that particular therapy.  But, as I have noted before, from my research in this subject, they usually don't recommend chemo for a tumor that is less than 1cm with no node involvement - radiation, yes, that is I believe always prescribed for those of us who have lumpectomies.  Please let me know how you made out and if they found your tumor to be larger than what was originally believed. And I am so glad you are feeling better! Big (yet gentle) hugs, Maria
Posts.Title: Grade change Lories Lories

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2009 09:52PM Britt wrote: 51
Posts.Title: Poll - How old were you when dx with BC Times3 Minetta57

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2009 09:29AM Britt wrote: Hi, Barbe - Yes, it indeed sucks.  I have decided to go through with the ALND - BUT - I want to speak with  my BS - she hasn't returned my phone calls yet.  She was in surgery all day yesterday.  I am going to her office first thing Monday morning to get a copy of my updated and corrected path report and to make an appt to discuss the surgery with her sometime next week.  My rad onco and med onco appts are on Wednesday.  You are lucky they sent your specimens to a large path centre (I love the British/Canadian spelling of that word) to be certain.  Well worth the three week wait.  yes, I am still a little upset, since I have been healing very nicely and have full mobility in my right arm.  Well, I look at it this way: I will be healed enough sufficiently when I have the surgery on 2/10 - I am going to tell BS I only want the Level 1 nodes taken out.  Better safe than sorry.  Thanks for your concern - and I will continue to keep everyone posted.
Posts.Title: Typographical Error on Pathology Report Britt Britt

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2009 10:12AM Britt wrote: Hi, Liz - Thank you so much for sharing your experience with me - your tumor size was very similar to mine - and you had 8mm of cancer in the one sentinel and I had 2mm - but I am grade 2.  You are VERY lucky your surgeon caught it during surgery and that he is a firm believer in doing the level 1 nodes - and also fortunate that your treatment was at Johns Hopkins and your surgeon is the Chief of Surgery.  So far, I have one positive node (sentinel) and one negative - fabulous you only had 8 nodes in level one and 6 turned out to be negative!!!!  Great to hear you  had no problems with lymphedema or pain in the area - and that you opted for rads.  So apparently you did not receive chemo treatments?  Please let me know.  Liz, your post has cheered me up immensely and has provided much-needed encouragement! Have a wonderful day!  Maria
Posts.Title: Typographical Error on Pathology Report Britt Britt

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2009 02:54PM - edited Feb 6, 2009 02:56PM by Britt Thanks, Deanna.  It was one of the toughest decisions I ever had to make in my life (at the risk of sounding melodramatic!)  but once I reached it, I was at peace with it.  Yes, just level 2 nodes.  I know full well how sneaky BC can be.  And, surprisingly enough, I am rather relieved I am not a candidate for the Oncotype test - that would mean more waiting - and then if the score were in a '"grey" area, then even more decision making.  And you are absolutely correct - all we can do is try everything possible, and then everything is in God's hands.  Right now just taking one day at a time and checking out wigs! Take care and thank you so very much for your encouragement - Big hugs back to you! Maria
Posts.Title: Typographical Error on Pathology Report Britt Britt

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2009 01:56PM Britt wrote: Thanks, Deanna - yes, a few more hurdles, but finding out the nodes are negative was a huge relief! I am definitely following your advice to rest up to get strong for Round Seventeen (that's what it feels like!!!!)  Will definitely keep everyone updated . . .  And BIG hugs back to you! Maria
Posts.Title: Typographical Error on Pathology Report Britt Britt

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2009 09:19PM - edited Jan 28, 2009 09:20PM by Britt Revkat - That's exactly what I would like to know.  Is it worth it, ultimately?  I have read that there are two schools of thought on the further removal of nodes - one school is that it is unnecessary, that it has nothing to do with a cure rate, but just a diagnostic tool.  The other is take them all out, it has everything to do with a cure rate, etc.  All I know is if I go ahead with the ALND and they take out 17 (or even more!!!) good nodes, I am going to be in Total Xena Meltdown Mode.  I am so angry you had to go through with the ALND - and you are right - it didn't change your treatment, and you lost 17 good nodes.  And lots of pain and lymphedema.  Did your BS give you an option - or did she stress that it was absolutely necessary?  Sometimes I wonder if they are just afraid of a possible med mal suit or something.  Forgive me but I am still rather perturbed - but thanks for sharing your experience and putting out a really good question!  Hope we get some answers to this one!!!!! Xena
Posts.Title: Typographical Error on Pathology Report Britt Britt

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2009 10:03PM Britt wrote: Well, for what it's worth - did the calculations bsOK so very kindly suggested, with path report in front of me - and according to that, I have a 7% chance of other nodes being affected. Will mention this to  my BS, no doubt! (she got her training at Duke) Thanks again, bsOK!!!!!
Posts.Title: Typographical Error on Pathology Report Britt Britt

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2009 10:29PM Britt wrote: Hi, unlimited! Well, the size of the tumor that was taken out was 2.3cm - the amount of cancer found in the sentinel node was 0.2cm (2mm - borderline micromets) so from what I read because of my tumor size and 1 positive node that makes me a Stage IIb (I think?) - and my B/R score was 6, so that's a Grade 2.  Gosh - I hope I did this correctly!  Sorry if I did not!
Posts.Title: Typographical Error on Pathology Report Britt Britt

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2009 09:44PM Britt wrote: Revkat - That's what my BS told me, also - but during the surgery the sentinel node didn't show anything.  At the hospital on the day of my surgery, I signed a release stating "lumpectomy, SND and ALND if necessary."  I wish they had found the sentinel to be positive during surgery - could have had it all over with now. Going to check out the website bsOK recommended - thanks again - Maria
Posts.Title: Typographical Error on Pathology Report Britt Britt

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2009 12:39PM Britt wrote: Hi all -  NODES ARE NEGATIVE!!!!!! Here is my latest update re ALND surgery that occurred on Tuesday, 2/10 - Wearing a drain - BIG HASSLE but getting used to it. Have purchased two lovely post-surgery camisoles from Amoena that have pockets for drains that are detachable.  They are rather like elongated sports bra with no snaps or hooks - one steps into it - they have great support and are made of cotton/spandex - very soft and also suitable for when one goes through radiation.  I highly recommend them.  They are also cute and kind of sexy-looking!  (check out the Amoena website for details) - they are also good for post-mast procedures - have inserts in the bra sections for foobs (which also came with each cammie - they come in white and nude). Had post-op consult with BS today - nine nodes in all were taken out - and I am happy to say that ALL ARE NEGATIVE!  Drain output still over 30 ccs for 24 hours two days in a row (which is when they will take out drain) - now down to 50ccs - so drain staying in for several more days.  Have visiting nurse coming every day to monitor the flow, check vitals, etc. - prescribed by BS. Next step is bone scan, CT scan and echo on 2/24 - then consult with med onco on 3/2 to discuss results of scans and echo and which chemo cocktail will be right for me (will they serve it in a martini glass?  Oh, wishful thinking!) So, although the operation has not been without pain - right arm is sore and rather numb - slowly beginning to exercise it with LE exercises - and despite the threat of LE which I must monitor for the rest of my life, I am relieved.  It was worth it for the peace of mind. I wish for all of you blessings and thank you all for your good wishes and prayers.   Yes, it was a tough decision to make, but I am now glad that I did. Doing a little happy dance at the moment - hope they didn't make another typo! Hugs to all - Maria
Posts.Title: Typographical Error on Pathology Report Britt Britt

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2009 08:52PM Britt wrote: Hi all - Thanks so much for responding and comisserating - I am in a quandry at the moment - 0.2cm equals 2mm, which is the absolute borderline for micromets - so technically it is still considered (barely) a micromet.  I am going to discuss with BS the pros and cons of the ALND - and I am thinking of either NOT having this surgery and just treat it aggressively with chemo and rads and of course hormone blockers, or having the surgery for "peace of mind."  What leads me to really consider the former is that the other node they took out was totally negative (or did they make a mistake with that one, also?)  Deanna, when did they finally tell you your sentinel node was not clear - shortly after your surgery?  And was it diagnosed correctly?  I am really beginning to not trust my hospital's pathology department! Any input would be appreciated - thanks so much - and thanks for the good wishes! Maria
Posts.Title: Typographical Error on Pathology Report Britt Britt

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2009 09:28PM Britt wrote: Deanna - OMG!!!! What an experience you had!  I am seriously considering getting a second opinion myself.  Similar thing happened with me - was told after my lump and SNB that margins were clear and no node involvement as far as BS could tell.  Then the path report said tiny micromets found in SNB - the other node taken out was clear.  BS gave me the option at the time for ALND but said it was not really necessary since the cancer was so teeny.  So here I go, merrily on my way, healing very nicely, great mobility in my arm, etc.  Made appts with rad and med oncos for next week.  Then the phone call today.  You know how I felt - it was an out of body experience - but I did express my anger at the path department.  What I am afraid of is that they may have misdiagnosed the other node, also - since they are SO gung-ho about the ALND - apparently not giving me a choice this time.  But I am speaking with my BS tomorrow and will discuss pros and cons and also tell her I am not happy with the path department and want a second opinion.  That's it.  Your experience has helped me to make my decision!  Thanks so much! Xena
Posts.Title: Typographical Error on Pathology Report Britt Britt

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2009 11:13AM Britt wrote: Hi, Liz - thanks for sharing your history and your experiences.  I ws dx at age 51 and I am still pre-menopausal.  I asked my BS to order the Oncotype Dx test and I have to follow up to see if she has done so.  I meet with my medical onco this coming Wednesday.  I realize that most med oncos will strongly suggest chemo if one's tumor is larger than 2 cms - but if the ALND proves the nodes are negative, and the Oncotype Dx scores low, then I will opt for Tamoxifen or an AI and rads.  I have some time - will still have to heal after ALND before they start any treatment.  I have also read that certain node negative women with tumors 1cm or less are getting chemo.  Of course, I am still in limbo re treatment until I find out if any of the nodes taken out are negative or positive. Oh well, back to looking at post-ALND bras!  Any suggestions? Have a great weekend and thanks again - and it is also inspiring  that you had little difficulty with chemo.
Posts.Title: Typographical Error on Pathology Report Britt Britt

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2009 12:35PM Britt wrote: Hi, all - For what it's worth, here is my update: Surgery still on for this Tuesday.  After long discussions with BS, rad onco and med onco, lots of research, etc. I have come to believe that this decision will be right for me - peace of mind, etc. Also found out from rad onco and med onco that I am not a candidate for Oncotype DX - my insurance will not cover it since I am node positive and pre-menstrual - also, there was a bit of a complication with my lumpectomy - the tissue was taken out to the chest wall in order to obtain clear margins.  I am happy they were able to save my breast,however, but chemo is deemed to be necessary. So - one week after surgery, 2/17 (if drains are out) med onco scheduled me for a bone scan, CT scan and echocardiogram at the hospital.  I then meet with med onco on 2/23 to discuss results and appropriate chemo cocktail - which will depend upon whether any other nodes are found to be positive and of course results of the scans.  I must admit I always sensed that I would need chemo, but the reality of it all was quite daunting.  Checking out wigs, etc. since med onco said I will most likely lose my hair. I am not a candidate for "chemo lite" since my tumor was 2.3 cm, margins to the chest wall, and node involvement. Will most likely start chemo first or second week of March - which is why I started a March 2009 chemo thread - no responses yet! So there it is.  Any input would be appreciated.  Thank you all so much again for concern, advice, suggestions, and sharing of similar experiences. Maria
Posts.Title: Typographical Error on Pathology Report Britt Britt

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2009 12:15PM Britt wrote: Hi, Shabby - I had one on New Year's Eve and thankfully it turned out negative!!!! If you want more information (both the good and the not so good) please refer to my post "MRI Guided Biopsies" under "Invasive Ductal Carcinoma" - now, please keep in mind everyone's experience is different! Good luck and blessings, Maria
Posts.Title: Anyone have an MRI core Biopsy? I need one. shabby6485 green71364

Posts.Content: Britt wrote: Hi everyone - Due to a questionable CT scan of the pelvic area indicating a thickening of the endometrial lining, I had an endometrial biopsy on 4/22. Called the gyno last Friday and results are not yet in. What I am asking about is if anyone else has ever had this procedure done prior to taking Tamoxifen.  My last period was on 4/11.  However, lo and behold, I started my period this Friday, 5/1 - very heavy bleeding and horrendous cramps.  This is not unusual for me - I usually experience periods of this virulence every three months.  I bled very slightly right after the biopsy for several hours and then it stopped. I am wondering if the biopsy itself brought on an early period.  Luckily today, the bleeding is beginning to dissipate and so are the cramps.  But I am still concerned. I did not have to have chemo due to low Oncotype score and am presently in the midst of radiation treatments - completed 19 to date.  Thanks for any input any of you may have.  Britt/Xena the Warrior Princess Dx 11/24/2008, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIB, Grade 2, 1/11 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Endometrial Biopsy side effects? Britt Britt

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2009 06:16AM Britt wrote: Hi, Tas - How long have you been bleeding? Mine lasted for a week, then stopped. It was also very painful and clotty.  If it has been over a week,please do call your doctor.  I know you are out of town right now, but you need to now what is going on.  Please keep me posted as to what you find out! Best wishes and good luck!  Maria
Posts.Title: Endometrial Biopsy side effects? Britt Britt

Posts.Content: Britt wrote: I wonder if anyone else has had this experience: My lumpectomy/SNB was 1/16/09.  Final path report and addendum discussed with BS last Friday, 1/23, in which two nodes were taken out - and the sentinel node was found to have 0.2mm - staged at NImi. Received a call from BS today, who was very upset. She just found out today from the pathology department that they made a typopgraphical error as to the amount of cancer in the sentinel node - it is actually 0.2 cm, NOT mm.  So they are scheduling the surgery for the axillary node operation for Feb. 10  I meet with radiation onco and medical onco next Wednesday. Needless to say, I am very angry.  Thanks for any input and for at least allowing me to vent. Britt/Xena the Warrior Princess Dx 11/24/2008, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIB, Grade 2, 1/11 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Typographical Error on Pathology Report Britt Britt

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2009 09:39PM Britt wrote: bsOK - Thanks SO very much for responding!  I will definitely checked out that website. Great to have a professional like you on the boards! Penny - Yes, it does suck, big time!   Thanks for your good wishes.  I will probably be up all night doing research, and also looking up drs for a second opinion - will keep you posted - I just know I am NOT going to be coerced into having a surgery I do not wish to have. unlimited - What an experience!  A BS who uses the "touch" method to determine if a node contains cancer cells?!?!?!?  Good for you that you did your research re levels of nodes - I will definitely make a note of that.  Sorry you developed mild lymphedema - but you had the extra-capsular extension - bummer.  Thanks for the encouragement - will keep you posted - best wishes and thanks to all
Posts.Title: Typographical Error on Pathology Report Britt Britt

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2009 10:39PM Britt wrote: Hi unlimited! That's ok - I am beginning to get Anticipatory Chemo Brain!  No problem - but your suggestion is something I am giving serious thought to - just Level 1 nodes removed.  But I'm still going to get a second opinion. It can't hurt at this point . . . And that's interesting you never got the size of the cancer in your node on your report - even though they initially made a typo, it was right up there as bold as could be! Big hugs to you, too!

My question is:  how long will I need to heal after the ALND surgery before I will be able to get chemo?  I meet with med onco and rad onco this Wednesday.
